ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Meniere's Disease (Left Ear)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Classic tetrad of symptoms present in the left ear: episodic vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus ('buzzy'), and aural fullness.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Chronic Otitis Media with Tympanic Membrane Perforation (Right Ear)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Confirmed by ENT observation, Type B tympanogram with large ear canal volume (3.9 cm3), and conductive hearing loss.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Vestibular Schwannoma (Left Ear)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss and unilateral tinnitus/fullness require exclusion of retrocochlear pathology via imaging.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Autoimmune Inner Ear Disease
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Can present with SNHL and vestibular symptoms, though usually bilateral and progressive; less likely than Meniere's given the episodic nature.

ordered_list.action: MRI of Internal Auditory Canals with contrast
ordered_list.rationale_short: To rule out retrocochlear pathology (e.g., vestibular schwannoma) given the asymmetric SNHL and unilateral symptoms.
To evaluate for the presence of endolymphatic hydrops, which supports a diagnosis of Meniere's disease.
To assess vestibular function and determine the extent of peripheral vestibular deficit.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Results indicate two distinct pathologies: a right-sided tympanic membrane perforation causing conductive loss, and a left-sided cochlear pathology (likely Meniere's disease) causing SNHL and vestibular symptoms.

tests.name: Pure-tone Audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right: Mild low-frequency conductive loss with air-bone gap. Left: Mild-to-moderate flat SNHL.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Right: Type B with large volume (3.9 mmhos), consistent with perforation. Left: Type A (normal).

tests.name: Speech Audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right: Excellent WRS (100%). Left: Reduced WRS (84%).

tests.name: Wideband Reflectance
tests.result_summary: Right: Low reflectance (consistent with perforation). Left: Normal.

proposed_items: Referral to Otolaryngologist (ENT) for medical management of Meniere's disease (e.g., diuretics, steroids) and evaluation of the right TM perforation.
Dietary modifications (low sodium, reduced caffeine/alcohol) to manage hydrops/vertigo.
Water precautions for the right ear (keep dry) to prevent infection.
Annual hearing monitoring or sooner if symptoms fluctuate.
Consideration for amplification (hearing aids) if hearing loss stabilizes and is bothersome, or surgical repair of right TM.
counseling_actions: Explain the dual diagnosis: a hole in the eardrum on the right and a likely inner ear fluid imbalance (Meniere's) on the left.
Counsel on the importance of keeping the right ear dry.
Discuss the nature of Meniere's disease, including the episodic nature of vertigo and potential for hearing fluctuation.
Safety counseling regarding vertigo attacks (e.g., driving, ladders).

escalation.rationale_short: Medical management of suspected Meniere's disease and surgical evaluation for TM perforation; MRI referral needed.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor hearing thresholds for fluctuation (common in Meniere's) and assess status of the right ear perforation.

expected_outcome: Confirmation of Meniere's disease diagnosis via response to treatment or further testing.
Stabilization of vertigo symptoms with medical management.
Maintenance of dry right ear or surgical repair of perforation.
